natural problem:
In a certain sequence the first term is $a_1 = 2007$ and the second term is $a_2 = 2008.$  Furthermore, the values of the remaining terms are chosen so that
\[a_n + a_{n + 1} + a_{n + 2} = n\]for all $n \ge 1.$  Determine $a_{1000}.$
natural solution: We know that $a_n + a_{n + 1} + a_{n + 2} = n$ and $a_{n - 1} + a_n + a_{n + 1} = n - 1.$  Subtracting these equations, we get \[a_{n + 2} - a_{n - 1} = 1,\]so $a_{n + 2} = a_{n - 1} + 1.$

Hence, the terms \[a_1 = 2007, \ a_4, \ a_7, \ a_{10}, \ \dots, \ a_{1000}\]form an arithmetic sequence with common difference 1. The common difference of 1 is added $\frac{1000 - 1}{3} = 333$ times, so $a_{1000} = 2007 + 333 = \boxed{2340}.$

a_0.formal problem:

fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "a 1 = 2007"
and h1 : "a 2 = 2008"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> a n + a (n + 1) + a (n + 2) = n"

 *)

theorem
fixes a :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "a 1 = 2007"
and h1 : "a 2 = 2008"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> a n + a (n + 1) + a (n + 2) = n"
shows  "a 1000 = 2340"
 proof-
